Baimore March 10 Our cilizens alarmed yester.
day morning, at about three o'clock, by the cry of FIRE
repairing to the spot, we found that it originated in
large warehouse in North Howard street. near Franklin
occupied by Mr. Henry Webb extensive wholesale
grocery and produce dealer The progress of the devour-
ing element was rapid that in short time the whole
interior of the house in which the fire commenced, and
adjoining one, hevocd to a similar object, in flames
As usual temen displayed the greatest daring and
activity, and do recolect have had feel
ings called upon than by which took
place Mr. Robert Norris, fireman conspicuous for his


mrepldy all occasions having charge of the pipe of
the Washington Hose Company and Mr. Branson, eng-
Of tho Union Company whose dauntlessness has long
been proverbial among his fellow citizens had led their
lines OF hose through story frame building, adjoining
those fire. and placed themselves the rno, in
der TO prevent it from being burned The roof of the
warehouse having tumbed in, it observed that its lofty
chimney and large portion Of the gable end were pres.
sed from the perpendicular position, and inclined conside-
raby towards the place where they stood Their friends


immediately informed them of the fact and cautioned them
against the danger but they not being abe owing their
position, 10 how much the wall leaned, believed that
the apprehcnsons Of their friends without foundation,
and persisted in retaining their station, and Norris
cambered up to the top of the chimney, that he might
lave better opportunity to give the stream of water
proper direction.


In a short time what had been apprehended occurred,
nearly the whole of The upper part Of the gable began to
move slowly first, but gradually increasing in velocity.
carrying death and destruction before it. Branson and
Norris their imminent danger, and the latter leapng
from the chimney which he standing the roof
endeavored to himself behind it rapid the
fall of the WALL that many persons supposed he had been
knocked BY it from the chimney, and in instant he and
his companou sank amidst the ruins of the frame building
which was literally crushed to pieces and a,tened To the
earth. The feelings experienced by those who look
ing beggar descriptions thrill OF horror pcrvaded the
whole crowd but it of short duration. few moments
only elapsed before both Of them rising from the
ruins apparently unlu waving their hands in triumph to
their friends who hailed them With hearty cheers 1t would
ard great satisfaction be able to stop this point of
our narrative. but unfortunately. NJ NHnr, esker and

The SCSQUEIIANNA.--The following re-


maj Ks from the Ithaca. New York. journal, o;ys.
further facts in Illustration of,e Importance Of the
susqnehanna to the people Of New York, the great
canal notwithstanding :-.. The Susquehanna Ry
er," says the journal. is already clear from ice.
and the hustle Of descending navigation has com
menced, with favourable prospects. 1t will be
some weeks yet, before the Erie canal will break


its icy feters and undergo such repairs as will rem
der it navigable. How futile, therefore, must be
the attempts to divert the commerce of the valley
Of the susquehanna from its present channel, by
means Of connecting canals. Even with the adj.
vantages possessed here of an immediate com,nu-
ncation with the Erie canal, we understand that
several OF our merchants have the present season.
sent quantities of Pork, Flour, Whiskey, &c. to be
conveyed down the Susquehanna; thus encounter
ing land conveyance oftrenty eight miles, for the
advantages Of an early market. If the citizens Of
Newtown and the valley Of the Chemung therefore,
have such strong predictions as they pretend for
canal transportation, they should not permit land
carriage Of eighteen miles the distance from Elmira
to the head of the Seneca to deter them from seek
ing their favorite channel of communication and

in the arrangement of the sailing of its packets be-
tween the United States aud Great Britain, by
which the place of their arrival and departure, in
the United States will be the port of Annapolis in
the State of Maryland.

regular toast was drank, in which the party are

From the ". z. Commercial Hdrertiser, March 81.


BETTER late thnn nerer.--About the time that
Morgan was taken from Batavia, it was stated that
several attempts were made by the freemasons to
burn the printing office of Miller, who was to be
Morgan's publisher. A reward of one hundred
dollars is offered by some individuals Of Batavia
(among whose names are those of Sheriff Thomp-
son, Surrogate Mix. &c.) for the discovery Of the
persons who attempted the outrage. One of the
Batavia papers has insinuated that this ncendiary
business was all sham--that Mler's office was
surrounded by houses of freemasons, which must
inevitably have been burnt with the office. We
think it would have been singular if the masons
had burnt themselves up in their rage. But this
is queer business, and it seems to be safest not
to believe any thing.
From the ". z. Commercial Advertiser, March 81

Messrs. Through the medium Of your
paper of the 9th inst. asked Mr. Harker very
civil question, viz. whether the Hon. Louis W Lane
was not the author Of an Address :. To the Federal
Members Of the Legislature Of Delaware" which
was published in the Delaware Gazette OF Nov. @.
1924, and which contained the following express
slons.


at is presumed that the ederaEsfs of Deiapnre, in

lTr TO HANG dstinguished citizens Of The United States an.
atr military Gu, applicable only regnes and 1sho HAS
ACTUALLY SHOT SIX MILITIA MEN Of he Untrd
Siates, WITHOUT A TRIAL.


To this civil question have obtained only an
indirect answer, and mention for the information
Of your readers, that Mr. Harker studiousy evades
the subject, and as he does not deny that Mr. NJ
Lane is the author of the Address, leave them to
draw their own conclusions.

Trays q .Weans-It is known to the public, that
hundreds OF dollars raised By private contribution,
besides the $500 given BY Gen. Eaton, were en-
ployed BY the advocates Of Gen. Jackson for the
presidency, to aid the editor of the late Columbian
Observer, in Philadelphia, in furiously assaing
Mr.. Adams, Mr.. Clay, Mr. Crawford, and their
friends and in yillfyng their characters, because
they stood in the way Of, or would not fall down
and worship the general as their idol Thirty
thousand dollars are also well understood to have
been raised, to pay Duff Green, ono of the must
accomplished blackguards in the nation, for print
ing and publishing the U. S. Telegraph, and for
circulating thousands his papers filled with abuse
OF Mr.. Clay, and Mr.. Adams and their friends.
free OF expense, among the people of the different
states. Other presses have sprung up since, that
have probably been established and supported in
the same way; as substituting and corrupting the
press, appears to be one principal mean, used by
the leaders Of the opposition, to effect their purpo
ses. In addition to what has already been dsclos-
ed on this subject, we were informed by an oppo-
sltion gentleman, short time since. who pretend
ed to know but who could not, it appears, keep the
secrets OF his party that they must succeed as they
had fund of S50.O0O, which they intended to EN-
ploy in establishing presses in the several states,
which were to be employed in writing down the
administration, and argued from this, that Mr. Ad-
ans could not be reelected. Attempts have been
made, we are well assured, to purchase two other
presses, that are now established or to employ their
editors in slandering the administration under the
promises Of large supplies and liberal support; but
happily without effects the editors of those papers
heing too pure, too honest and too high-mnded, to
be thus bought up. 1t is thus, that the leaders o.
the opposition, (not the people,, are determined to
control public opinion, and corruptly elevate them
selves to office, over the ruins of those. who now
preside over the nation. Trenton american.


Raleigh ~. G.. .uarch 16.-We have Just hear,
with feelings of deep regret, of the death Of the
Rev. Thomas Howard, Presiding Eker of the
Methodist Church in this Circuit, which happened
under circumstances peculiarly distressing. lie
was to have been married this week to young n
dy in Virginia, and as learn, was on his wav a
consummate his engagement, when his horse tool
fright, ran away and threw him out Of his gig, b.
which he was SO much injured, as to survive but il
short time.

awe copy the following article from the Ma

lie understands this kind Of business we'll, much

TIE MILITIA. A wrong view OF this sub
lect is taken by both the friends and enemies of
this institution string of queries has been put
biy the Secretary Of War to the General Officers
IN the several States, and among the rest one to
this purpose" Does any advantage arise from the
present system Of the hlitia.'' And the answer
has been that the present plan worse than useless


Now with great Difference to so great authority,
would suggest that peH organised militia is an
essential feature in republic, Il had almost said
primary nsttution,) but that it is not necessary
IN time Of profound peace that the militia should
be meH trained: and here lies the mistake, that
the organizing and training are confounded, and
on this rests the whole force of the objections to
militia musters 1t must be obvious that the mi
lltia cannot be organized without being mustered
in the different grades of companies battalions and
reeimcnts-and if this view of the subject is cor.
rect, militia musters very important and neces-
sary, and ought to be countenanced and supported
by every citizen. A FARMER.

The New York American gives the following az
the cause of the recently contemplated duel be
tween Mr.. Wright and Mr.. Saunders :-.s Genera
Saunders is the person whose resolution on the pub
lie printing has made so much talk in the House o.
Representatives. and is from North Carolina
Mr.. Wright is from Ohio. The cause of offence
we believe was, that Gen. Saunders after launch


ing anathemas against all officeseekers, office hold
ers, and others living upon the "public crib" was
reminded in the House by Mr.. Wright, that he
the aforesaid Saunders, had very recently sought
to fasten his teeth in the "public crib" in the
shape of Clerk of the Supreme Court of the United
States, for which office he was an unsuccessful ap-
pcant Mr.. Wright, referring to Mr.. SIS disap-
pointment, and to his resolution calling on Mr..
Clay for his reasons for removing certain printers.
suggested that the latter should be amended, as
also to ask from the Judges Of the Supreme Court
their reasons for having appointed another person
Clerk. This, and the comments thereupon, rous.
ed we believe, the wrath Of the gallant General to
the challenging point" True bill.l

upon dawnng Of attempt nate
. o,,i Of the u ion from anothcr.1 WASHINGTON.
FRIDAY, March %, 1927.

Colonial Trade Bill.-Our readers will remem-
bcr that at an early period Of the Session, bills
were reported in each House. by the appropriate
Committees, on the subject of our trade with the
English Colonies. These bills were essentially
the same. That in the senate was explained in a
sensible and able speech by Mr. Johnson, the Chair
man of the Committee which had reported it. As
far as we could observe, the explanation was sat
istactory and the bill generally approved by the
country. When the discussion came on, however,
Mr.. Smith, Of Maryland, moved to strike out the
whole bill. This motion was supported by the
votes Of the Opposition, as any motion will be which
promises to thwart or cmbarrass the measures of
Government. The motion prevailed and the new
bill, thus amended by Mr.. Smith. passed the SEN
ate, and sent to the House Representatives.
TO large majority of that House, this bill
acceptable; but the session was far advanced, and
it thought extremely desirable that some act of
legislation should be adopted. The House, there
fore, laid aside its own BILL took up that oithe SEN
ate, proposed an amendment, which was consider
ed as indispensable, and thus amended, passed the
Senate bill. The Senate declined acceding to
this amendment: and. as the House adhered to it.
the Senate with the full concurrence Of Mr. Smith.
chose rather to lose the bill altogether, than to a.
gree to the amendment of the House. The bill,
therefore, was ultimately lost in the Senate.


From publication of General Smith in Balti-
more paper, IL now appears, DIS We thinA. peyonu
doubt or contradiction, that he did not understand
the operation of his own measure. We have en-
tertained, habitually, great respect for General
Smith, as merchant of extensive information, and
member of Congress of high standing. We were
pleased at his recent eelection to the Senate 81
considering him as gentleman whose feelings were
candid, if not friendly, towards the Administration.
But must be permitted to say, that, on the sub
ject of the Colonial trade, he has, as we think,
subjected himself to very heavy responsibility
IF evil should ensue from what has been done, or
from what the Executive Government, in the ex-
isting state of law, may feel itself bound by indies
pensabe duty to do, it is not necessary for to say
after what we have here observed, what individual.
in our humble judgment, will be answerable. more
than any other, for that evil. Journal.
U'aslliington, Murch II.

full articles.headline: From the ". z. Commercial Advertiser, March 81
full articles.article:
From the ". z. Commercial Hdrertiser, March 81.


BETTER late thnn nerer.--About the time that
Morgan was taken from Batavia, it was stated that
several attempts were made by the freemasons to
burn the printing office of Miller, who was to be
Morgan's publisher. A reward of one hundred
dollars is offered by some individuals Of Batavia
(among whose names are those of Sheriff Thomp-
son, Surrogate Mix. &c.) for the discovery Of the
persons who attempted the outrage. One of the
Batavia papers has insinuated that this ncendiary
business was all sham--that Mler's office was
surrounded by houses of freemasons, which must
inevitably have been burnt with the office. We
think it would have been singular if the masons
had burnt themselves up in their rage. But this
is queer business, and it seems to be safest not
to believe any thing.

at is presumed that the ederaEsfs of Deiapnre, in

lTr TO HANG dstinguished citizens Of The United States an.
atr military Gu, applicable only regnes and 1sho HAS

To this civil question have obtained only an
indirect answer, and mention for the information

Lane is the author of the Address, leave them to
draw their own conclusions.

March 20. 30-6

Trays q .Weans-It is known to the public, that
hundreds OF dollars raised By private contribution,
besides the $500 given BY Gen. Eaton, were en-
ployed BY the advocates Of Gen. Jackson for the
presidency, to aid the editor of the late Columbian
Observer, in Philadelphia, in furiously assaing
Mr.. Adams, Mr.. Clay, Mr. Crawford, and their
friends and in yillfyng their characters, because
they stood in the way Of, or would not fall down
and worship the general as their idol Thirty
thousand dollars are also well understood to have
been raised, to pay Duff Green, ono of the must
accomplished blackguards in the nation, for print
ing and publishing the U. S. Telegraph, and for
circulating thousands his papers filled with abuse
OF Mr.. Clay, and Mr.. Adams and their friends.
free OF expense, among the people of the different
states. Other presses have sprung up since, that
have probably been established and supported in
the same way; as substituting and corrupting the
press, appears to be one principal mean, used by
the leaders Of the opposition, to effect their purpo
ses. In addition to what has already been dsclos-
ed on this subject, we were informed by an oppo-
sltion gentleman, short time since. who pretend
ed to know but who could not, it appears, keep the
secrets OF his party that they must succeed as they
had fund of S50.O0O, which they intended to EN-
ploy in establishing presses in the several states,
which were to be employed in writing down the
administration, and argued from this, that Mr. Ad-
ans could not be reelected. Attempts have been
made, we are well assured, to purchase two other
presses, that are now established or to employ their
editors in slandering the administration under the
promises Of large supplies and liberal support; but
happily without effects the editors of those papers
heing too pure, too honest and too high-mnded, to
be thus bought up. 1t is thus, that the leaders o.
the opposition, (not the people,, are determined to
control public opinion, and corruptly elevate them
selves to office, over the ruins of those. who now
preside over the nation. Trenton american.


Raleigh ~. G.. .uarch 16.-We have Just hear,
with feelings of deep regret, of the death Of the
Rev. Thomas Howard, Presiding Eker of the
Methodist Church in this Circuit, which happened
under circumstances peculiarly distressing. lie
was to have been married this week to young n
dy in Virginia, and as learn, was on his wav a
consummate his engagement, when his horse tool
fright, ran away and threw him out Of his gig, b.
which he was SO much injured, as to survive but il
short time.

full articles.headline: FOR THE Wa7cHM.iE.
full articles.article:
TIE MILITIA. A wrong view OF this sub
lect is taken by both the friends and enemies of
this institution string of queries has been put
biy the Secretary Of War to the General Officers
IN the several States, and among the rest one to
this purpose" Does any advantage arise from the
present system Of the hlitia.'' And the answer
has been that the present plan worse than useless


Now with great Difference to so great authority,
would suggest that peH organised militia is an
essential feature in republic, Il had almost said
primary nsttution,) but that it is not necessary
IN time Of profound peace that the militia should
be meH trained: and here lies the mistake, that
the organizing and training are confounded, and
on this rests the whole force of the objections to
militia musters 1t must be obvious that the mi
lltia cannot be organized without being mustered
in the different grades of companies battalions and
reeimcnts-and if this view of the subject is cor.
rect, militia musters very important and neces-
sary, and ought to be countenanced and supported
by every citizen. A FARMER.

The New York American gives the following az
the cause of the recently contemplated duel be
tween Mr.. Wright and Mr.. Saunders :-.s Genera
Saunders is the person whose resolution on the pub
lie printing has made so much talk in the House o.
Representatives. and is from North Carolina
Mr.. Wright is from Ohio. The cause of offence
we believe was, that Gen. Saunders after launch


ing anathemas against all officeseekers, office hold
ers, and others living upon the "public crib" was
reminded in the House by Mr.. Wright, that he
the aforesaid Saunders, had very recently sought
to fasten his teeth in the "public crib" in the
shape of Clerk of the Supreme Court of the United
States, for which office he was an unsuccessful ap-
pcant Mr.. Wright, referring to Mr.. SIS disap-
pointment, and to his resolution calling on Mr..
Clay for his reasons for removing certain printers.
suggested that the latter should be amended, as
also to ask from the Judges Of the Supreme Court
their reasons for having appointed another person
Clerk. This, and the comments thereupon, rous.
ed we believe, the wrath Of the gallant General to
the challenging point" True bill.l

full articles.headline: U'aslliington, Murch II.
full articles.article:
Colonial Trade Bill.-Our readers will remem-
bcr that at an early period Of the Session, bills
were reported in each House. by the appropriate
Committees, on the subject of our trade with the
English Colonies. These bills were essentially
the same. That in the senate was explained in a
sensible and able speech by Mr. Johnson, the Chair
man of the Committee which had reported it. As
far as we could observe, the explanation was sat
istactory and the bill generally approved by the
country. When the discussion came on, however,
Mr.. Smith, Of Maryland, moved to strike out the
whole bill. This motion was supported by the
votes Of the Opposition, as any motion will be which
promises to thwart or cmbarrass the measures of
Government. The motion prevailed and the new
bill, thus amended by Mr.. Smith. passed the SEN
ate, and sent to the House Representatives.
TO large majority of that House, this bill
acceptable; but the session was far advanced, and
it thought extremely desirable that some act of
legislation should be adopted. The House, there
fore, laid aside its own BILL took up that oithe SEN
ate, proposed an amendment, which was consider
ed as indispensable, and thus amended, passed the
Senate bill. The Senate declined acceding to
this amendment: and. as the House adhered to it.
the Senate with the full concurrence Of Mr. Smith.
chose rather to lose the bill altogether, than to a.
gree to the amendment of the House. The bill,
therefore, was ultimately lost in the Senate.


From publication of General Smith in Balti-
more paper, IL now appears, DIS We thinA. peyonu
doubt or contradiction, that he did not understand
the operation of his own measure. We have en-
tertained, habitually, great respect for General
Smith, as merchant of extensive information, and
member of Congress of high standing. We were
pleased at his recent eelection to the Senate 81
considering him as gentleman whose feelings were
candid, if not friendly, towards the Administration.
But must be permitted to say, that, on the sub
ject of the Colonial trade, he has, as we think,
subjected himself to very heavy responsibility
IF evil should ensue from what has been done, or
from what the Executive Government, in the ex-
isting state of law, may feel itself bound by indies
pensabe duty to do, it is not necessary for to say
after what we have here observed, what individual.
in our humble judgment, will be answerable. more
than any other, for that evil. Journal.
